parts.title: Unlocking Potential with Mindset Shift
parts.body: Have you ever thought something you wanted was out of reach? Julia Pimsleur’s 'Go Big Now' introduces us to mindset practices that can boost confidence and help us reach goals that seem impossible. Successful individuals have powerful mindsets, which help them stay positive (*despite challenges*) and achieve more. In a spinning class anecdote, Julia reflects on powerful mindset tools learned through NLP, coaching, and personal experience. As we build our mindset, akin to physical fitness, we become mentally resilient, helping us overcome obstacles and thrive during setbacks — like in her story of navigating the 2020 pandemic. With a structured approach to mindset, Julia illustrates how anyone can adopt these keys to unlock their full potential.

parts.title: Mindset Keys to Embrace Change
parts.body:
Mindset Keys & Positive Shifts

When we wish for a life change, doing something different is necessary. If we continue old habits, we remain unchanged. This section emphasizes we need to try new behaviors, even when they feel uncomfortable or "not me." Critical Reminder: - "If you want something you've never had, you'll need to do something you've never done." - Engage with activities from the book for real changes, even if you think you "get it" intellectually. The exercises help create mindset shifts and moving beyond intellectual understanding to action brings mastery. By ignoring the exercises, you deny yourself possible learnings and transformation.

parts.title: Understanding and Using RAS
parts.body: We constantly process millions of bits of information every second. Thankfully, our Reticular Activating System (RAS) acts as a filter, deciding what to bring to our attention and what to ignore. This allows us to sift through sensory overload and focus on what's important. However, our RAS can present a biased version of reality. Thus, learning to filter differently allows us to shape our reality to pursue our goals over reasons for not achieving them. Each person experiences a unique reality because their RAS decides what information is perceived as truth. This understanding helps develop the “Go Big Mindset,” where you focus on your personal vision rather than others' opinions. By accepting that everyone has their own subjective reality, one can choose results over reasons, thereby changing the outcome and avoiding a cycle of confirmation bias where one constantly looks for data supporting assumed perceptions.

parts.title: Achieving Go Big Goals: Overcoming Internal Barriers
parts.body: When you set a Go Big Goal, it should be exciting, a bit daunting, and feel like a significant step forward. The key to achieving big goals is to understand why they matter to you. Studies show that intrinsic motivations (like personal growth and joy) are stronger than extrinsic ones (like money or status). To achieve your goals, it's vital to grasp your internal drivers and remain motivated. This means understanding what your goal will bring to your life and how it fits into your broader vision of personal fulfillment. Reflect on what changes will happen once you achieve it, both practically and emotionally. Self-sabotage can occur when your "happiness level" feels too high, often termed the "Upper Limit Problem" (ULP). When nearing significant success, many unintentionally create obstacles to reset their happiness to a familiar level. It's important to recognize this pattern and consciously make choices to break through this limit. Identify your potential ULP patterns, rescript your mindset, and rewrite your personal story to overcome these barriers and fully pursue your ambitions, painting a new narrative for who you are and what you can achieve.

parts.title: Reframing Childhood Stories and the Power of "Done Decisions"
parts.body: The author explores how perceptions of childhood can differ, as evidenced by a conversation with her brother. She reflects on her own financial struggles as motivation for her work ethic and achievements. Influenced by this realization, she draws inspiration from books like Kate Northrup's Money: A Love Story and Jen Sincero's You Are a Badass, ultimately reframing her childhood scarcity as a superpower that fuels her coaching practice. Transitioning from "scarcity thinking" to "abundance thinking" has empowered both her and her clients. Pimsleur discusses how gritty perseverance can hinder growth in business leadership roles. To expand her company and gain venture capital, she had to transform her self-story from a struggling "scholarship kid" to a confident CEO. Emphasizing belief in oneself, she encourages creating "done decisions"—detailed, time-bound, positive commitments—as opposed to vague "hopeful decisions." This distinctive approach helps solidify intentions and bridge gaps between aspirations and fruition, allowing for structured growth and personal development pursuits.

parts.title: Overcoming Financial and Psychological Hurdles
parts.body: The author faced a significant decision: invest in an expensive training in Australia despite financial struggles post-divorce. After an "amygdala hijack," she calmed down, setting a clear goal of attending this training. To overcome financial limitations, she crowdsourced frequent-flyer miles from friends, successfully gathering 127,000 miles needed for the journey. Through risk-taking and persistence, she secured the funds needed for training by accepting new coaching clients, demonstrating the power of determination and resourcefulness. The story underscores the importance of overcoming limiting beliefs to achieve desired outcomes. It highlights how determination and creative problem-solving can enable the realization of goals, even in challenging circumstances. By turning financial hurdles into an opportunity for growth, she exemplifies the transformative impact of actively pursuing one's aspirations.

parts.title: Achieve Big Goals with Resilience
parts.body: To achieve big goals despite setbacks, remember three key steps: have methods at your fingertips to raise your energy, take massive action even when it feels hard, and focus on what you want rather than dwelling on negatives. This approach builds resilience, helping you navigate life's inevitable twists and turns with enthusiasm. Use tools like tracking your wins to boost confidence, celebrating small successes to create a positive cycle, finding accountability partners for mutual progress, and learning from those who've overcome odds. Engage in self-care to avoid burnout, surround yourself with other high achievers, maintain a daily gratitude practice for mental health, increase physical activity for emotional benefits, and always ask yourself, "What could go right?" to stay optimistic.

parts.title: Accepting Help and Self-Care
parts.body: "Take the Donuts" is about accepting help and avoiding the pitfalls of being a high achiever who ignores self-care. Palmer uses Thoreau's story to illustrate how even those seeking independence need support. This metaphor urges you to accept assistance to prevent burnout and improve your journey towards big goals. By accepting help, you bolster your ability to overcome setbacks and achieve monumental changes without sacrificing your health.

parts.title: Utilizing Mindset Keys Daily
parts.body: In the conclusion of the book, the author emphasizes the importance of using mindset keys in everyday life. These keys are essential tools for achieving major life goals and improving one's quality of life. The author shares the importance of teaching these keys to others carefully, without judgment or unsolicited advice, as doing so can help reinforce one's own understanding and mastery of the concepts. Through teaching and sharing, the overall mindset strength of communities and individuals can be improved, leading to more collective success.

parts.title: About Julia Pimsleur
parts.body: Julia Pimsleur is a well-known scaling coach and mindset expert. She created Million Dollar Women (MDW), a social venture dedicated to helping one million women entrepreneurs boost their annual revenues to $1 million. This mission is close to her heart due to her experience as the CEO of Little Pim, a successful children's language program that received venture capital backing - a rarity for women-led ventures. Through MDW, she's empowering women with tools and support via online business programs and the annual Million Dollar Women Summit. Pimsleur's journey includes raising over $26 million in funds from various sources and sharing her expertise in fundraising and entrepreneurial strategies by teaching at Parsons / The New School. She comes from a lineage of pioneering educators, with her father being Dr. Paul Pimsleur, a renowned figure in language teaching. Residing in Manhattan, she balances her professional commitments with personal interests like scuba diving and her French cultural affinity. For more insights or connection, Julia Pimsleur can be followed on social media or visited at her [website](https://juliapimsleur.com).
